Miller by Gage Skidmore.jpg | caption = Miller at the 2017 [[San Diego Comic-Con]] | alt = Miller at the 2017 San Diego Comic-Con | birth_name = Todd Joseph Miller | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1981|06|04}} | birth_place = [[Denver|Denver, Colorado]], U.S. | alma mater = [[George Washington University]] | occupation = Actor, stand-up comedian, producer, writer | years_active = 2007–present | spouse = {{marriage|Kate Miller|2015}} | website = {{official website|http://www.tjmillerdoesnothaveawebsite.com}} }}
'''Todd Joseph Miller''' (born June 4, 1981) is an American actor, stand-up comedian, producer, and writer.<ref name=NYTimes-QA-SiliconValley-2016>{{cite news|last1=Ryzik|first1=Melena|title=Q. and A. With T.J. Miller: ‘Silicon Valley’ and the Mucinex Phlegm Ball|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/24/arts/television/q-and-a-with-tj-miller-silicon-valley-and-the-mucinex-phlegm-ball.html|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=April 20, 2016}}</ref>
In 2008, he made his acting debut in ''[[Cloverfield]]'', and from 2010 to 2019, he voiced Tuffnut Thornton in all three ''[[How to Train Your Dragon (franchise)|How to Train Your Dragon]]'' films. From 2014 to 2017, he starred as Erlich Bachman in the [[HBO]] sitcom ''[[Silicon Valley (TV series)|Silicon Valley]]'',<ref name=NewYorker-SiliconValley-2016>{{cite news|last1=Marantz|first1=Andrew|title=How 'Silicon Valley' Nails Silicon Valley|url=https://www.newyorker.com/culture/culture-desk/how-silicon-valley-nails-silicon-valley|work=[[The New Yorker]]|date=June 9, 2016}}</ref> and also played [[Marvel Comics]] character [[Weasel (Marvel Comics)|Weasel]] in 2016's ''[[Deadpool (film)|Deadpool]]'' and its 2018 sequel, ''[[Deadpool 2]]''. Miller also has had starring roles in films such as ''[[Yogi Bear (film)|Yogi Bear]]'', ''[[She's Out of My League]]'', ''[[Transformers: Age of Extinction]]'', ''[[Big Hero 6 (film)|Big Hero 6]]'', ''[[Office Christmas Party]]'', ''[[The Emoji Movie]]'' and ''[[Ready Player One (film)|Ready Player One]]''.<ref name=DenverPost-HighPlainsComedyFest-2017>{{cite news|last1=Wenzel|first1=John|title=T.J. Miller on leaving Silicon Valley, his summer of controversy, and losing his mind: "I was stunting"|url=http://theknow.denverpost.com/2017/08/23/tj-miller-interview-high-plains-denver-2017/156063/|work=[[The Denver Post]]|date=August 23, 2017}}</ref>
==Early life and education== Miller was born in [[Denver|Denver, Colorado]], the son of Leslie Miller, a clinical psychologist, and Kent Miller, an attorney from [[Chanute, Kansas]].<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3L-5GhQvAP8 TJ Miller performs Standup Comedy at ''Mel's'' on Main, Chanute, Kansas]</ref><ref name=DenverPost-YogiBear-2010>{{cite news|last1=Husted|first1=Bill|title=Husted: 2010 is Miller time for Denver kid who made it big|url=http://www.denverpost.com/2010/12/11/husted-2010-is-miller-time-for-denver-kid-who-made-it-big|work=[[The Denver Post]]|date=December 11, 2010}}</ref><ref name=WeekendEdition-Deadpool-2016>{{cite news|last1=Blair|first1=Elizabeth|title=Comic T.J. Miller: Trained Clown And Student Of Nietzsche|url=https://www.npr.org/2016/02/13/466462562/comic-t-j-miller-trained-clown-and-student-of-nietzsche|work=[[Weekend Edition]] Saturday|publisher=[[NPR]]|date=February 13, 2016|format=Includes audio}}</ref> His Christian father is of English, Swedish, German, and Scottish ancestry, whereas his Jewish mother is of German, Austrian, and Russian descent.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=to6LurY7DJo|title=T J Miller [Unknown? Facts] - Hosts podcast "Cashing in ...|first=|last=QHD|date=August 4, 2016|publisher=|accessdate=December 12, 2016|via=YouTube}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.jta.org/2016/12/09/arts-entertainment/jewish-comedian-t-j-miller-arrested-in-altercation-over-trump-with-uber-driver|title=Jewish comedian T.J. Miller arrested in altercation over Trump with Uber driver - Jewish Telegraphic Agency|website=www.jta.org|accessdate=10 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/jewish-comedian-arrested-for-uber-fight-over-trump/|title=Jewish comedian arrested for Uber fight over Trump|publisher=|accessdate=10 April 2018}}</ref>
He attended [[Graland|Graland Country Day School]] and graduated from Denver's [[East High School (Denver)|East High School]], where he participated in drama productions.<ref name=DenverPost-YogiBear-2010/> His drama teacher at East High, Melody Duggan, confirms Miller was a "typical class clown", but said he was much more intuitive than the average teenager. "He understands the frailty of the human condition better than any kid I've ever had.<ref name=WeekendEdition-Deadpool-2016/>
In 2003, Miller graduated from [[George Washington University]] in [[Washington, D.C.]] with a B.A. in psychology with a concentration in [[situation theory]] and [[social influence]].<ref name=GWHatchet-Carpoolers-2007>{{cite news|last1=Kabas|first1=Marisa|title=GW alum stars in ABC’s new primetime show|url=https://www.gwhatchet.com/2007/10/01/gw-alum-stars-in-abcs-new-primetime-show|work=The GW Hatchet|date=October 1, 2007}}</ref><ref name=FerrisStateTorch-Homecoming-2014>{{cite news|last1=Anderson|first1=Devin|title=Real Talk with TJ Miller|url=http://fsutorch.com/2014/10/08/real-talk-tj-miller|work=The Ferris State Torch|publisher=[[Ferris State University]]|date=October 8, 2014}}</ref>
At GWU, he was a member of the comedy group receSs and the [[Lambda]] chapter of [[Phi Sigma Kappa]] fraternity.<ref name=DenverPost-YogiBear-2010/> While in college, Miller studied the circus arts at Frichess Theatre Urbain in [[Paris]], and attended the [[British American Drama Academy]] in [[London]], where he studied [[Shakespeare]] for a summer.<ref name=WeekendEdition-Deadpool-2016/><ref name=Groundlings-Bio>{{cite web|title=Performers: T.J. Miller|url=http://www.groundlings.com/performers/performer-details.aspx?performerID=446|website=[[The Groundlings]]|accessdate=September 6, 2017}}</ref>
==Career==
===Stand-up=== After college, Miller moved to [[Chicago]] and began to perform improvisation and stand-up comedy, performing with many local troupes.<ref name=ChicagoMag-SiliconValley-2015>{{cite news|last1=Heidemann|first1=Jason|title=Silicon Valley Star T.J. Miller Says Nietzsche Made Him Funny|url=http://www.chicagomag.com/Chicago-Magazine/April-2015/Silicon-Valley-Star-TJ-Miller-on-the-Forces-That-Made-Him-Funny/|work=[[Chicago (magazine)|Chicago]]|date=1 April 2015|language=en}}</ref><ref name=SecondThoughts-SecondCity-2007>{{cite news|last1=Campus Activities Magazine|title=TJ Miller|url=http://camimprovsecondcity.blogspot.com/2007/12/tj-miller.html|work=Second Thoughts from The Second City|date=3 December 2007}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.iowastatedaily.com/limelight/article_f49b70cc-a931-11e7-a7e6-33d21191683c.html|title=TJ Miller to perform in the Great Hall|last=@iowastatedaily.com|first=Emily.Urban|work=Iowa State Daily|access-date=2017-10-11|language=en}}</ref> He toured with [[The Second City]] for two years.<ref name=Groundlings-Bio /> In 2008, he was named one of [[Variety (magazine)|''Variety's'']] 10 Comics To Watch.<ref name=Variety-10ComicsToWatch-2008>{{cite news|last1=Frankel|first1=Daniel|title=T.J. Miller: 10 Comics to Watch|url=https://variety.com/2008/film/news/t-j-miller-1117988735/|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=July 10, 2008}}</ref>
In 2011, Miller released a comedy special, ''No Real Reason'', and a comedy album, ''Mash Up Audiofile'' in 2012.<ref name=LaughButton-NoRealReason-2011>{{cite news|title=T.J. Miller's "No Real Reason" keeps it weird, keeps it great|url=http://thelaughbutton.com/features/reviews/review-tj-millers-real-reason-weird-great|work=The Laugh Button|date=November 16, 2011}}</ref><ref name=AVClub-MashUpRecord-2012>{{cite news|last1=Heisler|first1=Steve|title=The best comedy albums of 2012|url=http://www.avclub.com/the-best-comedy-albums-of-2012-1798235973|work=[[The A.V. Club]]|date=December 10, 2012}}</ref>
In 2015, he was part of [[Funny or Die]]’s ''Oddball Comedy and Curiosity Festival,'' a touring show which included [[Amy Schumer]], [[Aziz Ansari]], and other comics.<ref name=KCStar-OddballFest-2015>{{cite news|last1=Niccum|first1=Jon|title=Comic actor T.J. Miller: An oddball among oddballs|url=http://www.kansascity.com/entertainment/performing-arts/article32375232.html|work=[[The Kansas City Star]]|date=August 26, 2015}}</ref>
On June 17, 2017, HBO premiered his hour-long stand-up special, ''T.J. Miller: Meticulously Ridiculous'', which was filmed in Miller's native Denver at the end of his 2016 ''Meticulously Ridiculous Tour''.<ref name=Deadline-HBO-MeticRidic-2017>{{cite news|last1=Petski|first1=Denise|title=HBO Sets Summer Premiere For Stand-Up Special From Silicon Valley's T.J. Miller|url=http://deadline.com/2017/04/silicon-valley-t-j-miller-standup-tour-hbo-comedy-special-1201788082|website=Deadline Hollywood|date=April 10, 2017}}</ref>
===Television=== Miller appeared frequently as a member of the "round table" on ''[[Chelsea Lately]]''. He appeared as Marmaduke Brooker in ''[[Carpoolers]]'', which ran for 13 episodes on [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] in 2007{{ndash}}2008. In 2012, he voiced Robbie Valentino on the Disney channel cartoon ''[[Gravity Falls]]''. On December 13, 2010, October 28, 2011, and June 14, 2012, he performed stand-up on ''[[Conan (talk show)|Conan]]''. On November 15, 2011, his stand-up special ''No Real Reason'' premiered on [[Comedy Central]]. In 2011, he hosted a special called ''Mash Up'', which was picked up in 2012 for a full season by Comedy Central.<ref name=Deadline-CC-MashUp-2012>{{cite news|last1=Andreeva|first1=Nellie|title=Comedy Central Greenlights Stand-Up Series Hosted By T.J. Miller|url=http://deadline.com/2012/02/comedy-central-greenlights-stand-up-series-hosted-by-t-j-miller-232149/|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=17 February 2012}}</ref><ref name=AVClub-CCMashUpReview-2011>{{cite news|last1=Heisler|first1=Steve|title=Mash Up|url=http://tv.avclub.com/mash-up-1798167913|work=[[The A.V. Club]]|date=11 March 2011}}</ref> He starred in the Fox TV series ''[[The Goodwin Games]]'' as Jimmy Goodwin.<ref>{{cite web|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|url=http://www.deadline.com/2012/06/t-j-miller-to-play-lead-on-new-fox-comedy-series-goodwin-games-in-recasting/|title=T.J. Miller To Play Lead On New Fox Comedy Series ‘Goodwin Games’ In Recasting|website=Deadline Hollywood|date=June 7, 2012|accessdate=October 8, 2017}}</ref>
Miller starred in the [[HBO]] sitcom ''[[Silicon Valley (TV series)|Silicon Valley]]'', which has been met with widespread critical acclaim and he won the [[Critics' Choice Television Award for Best Supporting Actor in a Comedy Series]] in 2015. In May 2017, Miller and HBO jointly announced that Miller will not be returning for the 5th season of ''Silicon Valley''.<ref name=Variety-SiliconValleyExit-2017>{{cite news|last1=Otterson|first1=Joe|title=T.J. Miller to Exit ‘Silicon Valley’ Ahead of Season 5|url=https://variety.com/2017/tv/news/tj-miller-exit-silicon-valley-season-5-1202444762|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=May 25, 2017}}</ref><ref name=HReporter-SiliconValley-Breakup-2017>{{cite news|last1=Sandberg|first1=Bryn Elise|title=T.J. Miller Says Leaving 'Silicon Valley' "Felt Like a Breakup"|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/tj-miller-says-leaving-silicon-valley-was-like-a-breakup-1016573|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=June 25, 2017}}</ref><ref name=Vulture-SiliconValleyExit-2017>{{cite news|last1=Marchese|first1=David|title=‘People Need a Villain’ - T.J. Miller Knows You Think He’s Crazy for Leaving Silicon Valley|url=http://www.vulture.com/2017/07/t-j-miller-on-leaving-hbo-silicon-valley.html|work=[[Vulture (website)|Vulture]]|date=July 23, 2017}}</ref>
As a commercial actor, he voices a talking ball of mucus in commercials for [[Mucinex]]<ref name=KCStar-OddballFest-2015/> and stars as Greg the Genie in a promotional campaign for [[Slim Jim (snack food)|Slim Jim]] meat snacks.<ref name=Uproxx-Commercials-2015>{{cite news|last1=Husband|first1=Andrew|title=T.J. Miller Tells Us Why He Thinks Making Funny Commercials Is Better Than Being On ‘SNL’|url=http://uproxx.com/tv/t-j-miller-interview/3/|work=[[Uproxx]]|date=30 September 2015}}</ref>
===Film=== In Miller's film debut, ''[[Cloverfield]]'', he appeared onscreen for only a few minutes, but his voice was heard in almost every scene as the character who videotaped most of the events depicted. In 2009, he played Cessna Jim in ''[[The Goods: Live Hard, Sell Hard]]'' and the dim-witted [[grindcore]] musician Rory in [[Mike Judge]]'s comedy ''[[Extract (film)|Extract]]''. In 2010, he co-starred in ''[[She's Out of My League]]'' as Stainer, played Brian the Concierge in ''[[Get Him to the Greek]]'' and appeared in a supporting role in the film ''[[Unstoppable (2010 film)|Unstoppable]]''.<ref name=DenverPost-YogiBear-2010 />
He voiced the character ‘Tuffnut’ in the Oscar-nominated animated films ''[[How to Train Your Dragon (film)|How to Train Your Dragon]]'' and ''[[How to Train Your Dragon 2]]''. He also played Dan in ''[[Gulliver's Travels (2010 film)|Gulliver's Travels]]'', released in December 2010. He played the supporting character of [[Ranger Jones]] in the live-action/animated ''[[Yogi Bear (film)|Yogi Bear]]'' 2010 film.<ref name=Variety-YogiBearReview-2010>{{cite news|last1=Chang|first1=Justin|title=Review: ‘Yogi Bear’|url=https://variety.com/2010/film/reviews/yogi-bear-1117944187/|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=December 13, 2010}}</ref>
Unlike his character on the cartoon show, he is "dumb-but-not-in-a-funny-way", according to the ''Buffalo News''.<ref name=BuffaloNews-YogiBearReview-2010>{{cite news|last1=Miller|first1=Melinda|title=Spoiling the fun; Film with potential winds up being mostly unbearable|url=http://buffalonews.com/2010/12/16/spoiling-the-fun-film-with-potential-winds-up-being-mostly-unbearable/|work=[[The Buffalo News]]|date=December 16, 2010}}</ref> He was cast in the part after two auditions; as a joke, he sent Warner Bros. an improvised video audition with an actual bear, though he had already been offered the part before they received it.<ref name=JordanVogtRoberts-YogiBearAudition-2009>{{cite web|title=T.J. Miller Auditions for Yogi the Bear|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fnOHz1U6xNs|website=JordanVogtRoberts|format=Video|date=October 28, 2009}}</ref>
In 2011, he appeared in the film ''[[Our Idiot Brother]]''. He had a cameo as administrative personnel for ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' in the 2012 film ''[[Rock of Ages (2012 film)|Rock of Ages]]''. He starred in the 2016 movie ''[[Search Party (film)|Search Party]]'' alongside [[Adam Pally]].<ref name=HReporter-SearchPartyCasting-2013>{{cite news|last1=Kit|first1=Borys|title='Search Party' Finds Its Stars, Begins Shooting Next Week|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/search-party-finds-stars-begins-444776|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=April 23, 2013}}</ref>
In 2014, he appeared in ''[[Transformers: Age of Extinction]]''.<ref name=HReporter-Transformers4Casting-2013>{{cite news|last1=Kit|first1=Borys|title=T.J. Miller Joins 'Transformers 4'|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/tj-miller-joins-transformers-4-559359|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=May 28, 2013}}</ref>
In November 2014, he was the voice of [[Fredzilla|Fred]] in the superhero CGI film ''[[Big Hero 6 (film)|Big Hero 6]]''. He also played [[Weasel (Marvel Comics)|Weasel]] in ''[[Deadpool (film)|Deadpool]]'' and ''[[Deadpool 2]]''. In 2017, he portrayed the voice of the main protagonist Gene, a [[meh]] emoji with abnormal expressions, in the animated ''[[The Emoji Movie]]''<ref name=EW-EmojiMovie-2016>{{cite news|last1=Snierson|first1=Dan|title='Silicon Valley' star T.J. Miller to voice lead character in emoji movie|url=http://ew.com/article/2016/07/17/emoji-movie-express-yourself-tj-miller-silicon-valley-deadpool/|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=17 July 2016}}</ref> which got extremely negative reception.
===Music=== On September 12, 2011, Miller released a comedy rap [[concept album]] titled ''The Extended Play E.P.'' The album features comedians [[Bo Burnham]], [[Doug Benson]], [[Pete Holmes]] and hip-hop artists [[Ugly Duckling]] and [[Johnny Polygon]].<ref name=AllMusic-ExtendedPlayEP-2011>{{cite web|last1=Jeffries|first1=David|title=The Extended Play EP - T.J. Miller|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/the-extended-play-ep-mw0002191297|website=[[AllMusic]]|date=September 25, 2011}}</ref>
In 2012, Miller released ''The Extended Play E.P. [[Illegal Art]] Remix Tape.''<ref name=ConsequenceOfSound-ExtendedEP-2012>{{cite news|last1=Coplanon|first1=Chris|title=Stream: T.J. Miller – The Extended Play E.P. Illegal Art ReMixTape (CoS Premiere)|url=https://consequenceofsound.net/2012/09/stream-t-j-miller-the-extended-play-e-p-illegal-art-remixtape-cos-premiere|work=[[Consequence of Sound]]|date=September 19, 2012}}</ref> Also in 2012, Miller released ''Mash Up Audiofile'' on Comedy Central Records to mixed reviews.<ref name=SpitTake-MashUpReview-2012>{{cite news|last1=Seabaugh|first1=Julie|title=T.J. Miller Mash Up Audiofile album review|url=http://www.thespittake.com/2012/11/12/t-j-miller-mash-up-audiofile-comedy-central-records/|work=The Spit Take|date=November 12, 2012}}</ref>
===Podcasting=== Miller started appearing on Chicago-based comedy Podcast Red Bar Radio in 2006 as a semi-regular co-host. He hosts a podcast with friend and fellow comedian [[Cash Levy]], titled ''Cashing in With TJ Miller'', which began airing in March 2012 on the Nerdist Network.<ref name=Nerdist-CashingInWithTJMiller>{{cite web|title=Cashing In with T.J. Miller|url=http://nerdist.com/podcasts/cashing-in-with-t-j-miller-channel/|website=Nerdist|language=en}}</ref> He is also a frequent guest on [[Doug Benson]]'s podcast ''Doug Loves Movies''.<ref name=ASTRecords-DougLovesMovies>{{cite web|title=Doug Loves Movies|url=http://astrecords.com/dlm/index.php|website=A Special Thing Records}}</ref>
==Personal life== In 2014, Miller became engaged to his longtime girlfriend, actress and mixed-media artist Kate, who changed her surname to Miller.<ref name=Vulture-SiliconValleyExit-2017/> They were married at the [[Denver Botanic Gardens]] on September 6, 2015.<ref name=TownAndCountry-Wedding-2016>{{cite news|last1=Sykes|first1=Logan|title=You've Never Seen Anything Like This Whimsical Art Deco-Inspired Wedding|url=http://www.townandcountrymag.com/the-scene/weddings/news/g1346/tj-miller-wedding|work=[[Town & Country (magazine)|Town & Country]]|date=December 9, 2016}}</ref><ref name=VanityFair-KateMiller-2017>{{cite news|last1=Harwood|first1=Erika|title=Kate Miller, Artist and Wife of T.J., Is O.K. Being Misunderstood|url=https://www.vanityfair.com/style/2017/08/kate-miller-is-ok-being-misunderstood|work=[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]|date=August 17, 2017}}</ref>
Miller described learning about an undiagnosed [[cerebral arteriovenous malformation]] on his right frontal lobe on the [[Pete Holmes]] podcast ''[[You Made It Weird with Pete Holmes|You Made It Weird]]'' on October 28, 2011. He stated that he became more philosophical, narrated his behaviors, and was unable to sleep while filming ''[[Yogi Bear (film)|Yogi Bear]]'' in [[New Zealand]] in 2010. His brain surgery was successful, though there was a 10 percent risk of fatality.<ref name=KCStar-OddballFest-2015 /><ref name=YouMadeItWeird-Episode2-2011>{{cite news|last1=Holmes|first1=Pete|last2=Miller|first2=T.J.|title=You Made It Weird #2: TJ Miller|url=http://nerdist.com/you-made-it-weird-2-tj-miller/|work=Nerdist|date=28 October 2011|language=en|format=Podcast}}</ref>
== Legal issues and controversies ==
=== Uber assault incident === On December 9, 2016, Miller was arrested and jailed in [[Los Angeles]] for allegedly assaulting a driver of the [[Uber]] car service company because of a debate he had with the driver over [[Donald Trump]], of whom Miller is an outspoken critic. He was released on his own recognizance after bail was set at $20,000.<ref name="People-UberArrest-2016">{{cite news|url=http://people.com/celebrity/silicon-valley-tj-miller-arrested-on-suspicion-of-battery-on-car-service-driver/|title=Silicon Valley’s T.J. Miller Arrested on Suspicion of Battery on Car Service Driver|last1=Stone|first1=Natalie|date=9 December 2016|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]}}</ref><ref name="Reuters-UberArrest-2016">{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-people-tjmiller/actor-t-j-miller-arrested-after-altercation-with-uber-driver-idUSKBN13Y2LE|title=Actor T.J. Miller arrested after altercation with Uber driver|last1=Dobuzinskis|first1=Alex|date=9 December 2016|work=[[Reuters]]}}</ref>
===Sexual assault allegations=== In late 2017, allegations against Miller from his college days back in 2001 resurfaced, part of a [[Me Too movement|movement of people]] coming forward with [[Weinstein effect|sexual abuse claims about Harvey Weinstein and other Hollywood insiders]]. An anonymous woman who attended [[George Washington University]] with Miller and his wife Kate told ''[[The Daily Beast]]'' reporter Asawin Suebsaeng that Miller (her then boyfriend)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://pagesix.com/2017/12/19/t-j-miller-accused-of-sexual-assault-domestic-violence|title=T.J. Miller and wife deny sexual assault allegations against him|date=19 December 2017|publisher=|accessdate=10 April 2018}}</ref> became violent with her during a sexual encounter; he allegedly choked, shook, and punched her in the mouth, all [[Non-consensual sex|without her consent]]. Suebsaeng attempted to contact witnesses and other people involved with the case, some of whom corroborated the accuser's story, adding that it was brought to the attention of the college at the time. Student conduct proceedings were held, the results of which are sealed, although it has been claimed{{by whom|date=August 2018}} that, despite Miller having graduated by that time, he was [[Expulsion (education)|expelled]] as a form of appeasement to the accuser.<ref>{{cite news|last=Suebsaeng|first=Asawin|title='Silicon Valley' Star T.J. Miller Accused of Sexually Assaulting and Punching a Woman|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/silicon-valley-star-tj-miller-accused-of-sexually-assaulting-and-punching-a-woman|publisher=[[The Daily Beast]]|date=December 19, 2017|accessdate=January 2, 2018}}</ref>
The Millers responded to the allegations, characterizing the accuser as a vindictive former colleague in a campus comedy troupe who was asked to leave due to inappropriate behavior. The statement said that "[s]adly she is now using the current climate to bandwagon and launch these false accusations again", and also stated that her accusation "undermines the important movement to make women feel safe coming forward about legitimate claims against real known predators".<ref>{{cite news|last=Birnbaum|first=Debra|title=T.J. Miller Denies Sexual Assault Allegation|url=https://variety.com/2017/tv/news/tj-miller-sexual-assault-allegations-1202644917/|publisher=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=December 19, 2017|accessdate=January 2, 2018}}</ref>
===Amtrak bomb threat incident=== Miller was arrested on the night of April 9, 2018 at [[LaGuardia Airport]] in [[Queens]], [[New York (state)|New York]] on federal charges related to a [[Bomb threat|fake bomb threat]] made while aboard an [[Amtrak]] train. According to a [[United States Department of Justice|Department of Justice]] press release, he placed an [[Emergency telephone number|emergency call]] on March 18, 2018, and reported that a female passenger had "a bomb in her bag" while traveling on [[List of Amtrak routes|Amtrak Train 2256]] from [[Washington, D.C.]], toward [[Pennsylvania Station (New York City)|Penn Station]] in [[New York City]]. After authorities evacuated passengers and searched Amtrak Train 2256, it turned out that Miller was actually on [[List of Amtrak routes|Amtrak Train 2258]], which was also evacuated of passengers and searched.<ref>[https://www.cnn.com/2018/04/10/entertainment/tj-miller-arrest/index.html T.J. Miller arrested for alleged fake bomb threat], accessed April 10, 2018</ref> No evidence of any [[explosive device]] or materials was detected after officials stopped and inspected both trains. According to [[witness]]es interviewed by [[Amtrak Police|Amtrak investigators]], he appeared to be heavily [[Alcohol intoxication|intoxicated]] and involved "in hostile exchanges with a woman who was sitting in a different row from him in the first-class car", and that he had been removed from the train prior to his intended stop due to his intoxication. On April 10, 2018 he was released on a $100,000 bond following an appearance at a [[United States District Court for the District of Connecticut|federal court]] hearing in [[New Haven, Connecticut]]. If convicted, he could face up to five years in prison.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/04/10/entertainment/tj-miller-arrest/index.html|title=T.J. Miller arrested for alleged fake bomb threat|first=Lisa Respers France,|last=CNN|publisher=|accessdate=10 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.justice.gov/usao-ct/pr/new-york-man-charged-calling-false-bomb-threat-amtrak-train|title=New York Man Charged with Calling in False Bomb Threat from Amtrak Train|website=www.justice.gov|accessdate=10 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2018/04/t-j-miller-charged-calling-in-fake-bomb-threat-train-arrested-1202361644/|title=T.J. Miller Charged With Calling In Fake Bomb Threat|first=Denise|last=Petski|date=10 April 2018|publisher=|accessdate=10 April 2018}}</ref><ref name="VarietyBombThreat">{{cite news|last1=Khatchatourian|first1=Maane|title=T.J. ===Work misconduct accusations=== On July 18, 2018, actress [[Alice Wetterlund]], who recurred on ''[[Silicon Valley (TV series)|Silicon Valley]]'', a show in which Miller starred, took to [[Twitter]] to accuse Miller of inappropriate, unprofessional behavior on set, writing:
{{Quote|“I hope to not ruin it for you, but TJ Miller was a bully and petulant brat.”<ref name="WetterlundAccusation"/>}}
In response to her post, [[HBO]], the premium network that produces the series, released a statement declaring that “While this is the first time we have heard Alice Wetterlund comment on her experiences on ‘Silicon Valley,’ we are disappointed to learn of her concerns. HBO and the producers have always taken very seriously our responsibility to create a welcoming and congenial environment for everyone who works on the show.”<ref name="WetterlundAccusation">https://variety.com/2018/tv/news/silicon-valley-t-j-miler-1202877293/</ref>
